body: I saw this too. Can you compile debug build and repo? It could show where it throw.

@iSazonov 

Hum! I'm curious if this has to do with the last minute push of the PSReadLine 2.0.0-beta5.
It was working fine with Preview.3.

Correction!! I have to keep reminding me that the issue is with Windows 10 Insider WSL2.
Window 10 Build 1903 WSL1 works Great! I have no issues with PS7 Preview.4.

:)

This sounds to me like you installed pwsh as the root user (or maybe it's that the first you ran it, you ran it as root; I can't remember), and so the non-root user gets a very straightforward "access denied" (because the history file is owned by root; of course non-root won't have write access). I have a [setup script with this code](https://github.com/jazzdelightsme/nixSetup/blob/44242496b82b2685fa8b92b48c2c896dcbbb932c/moreSetup.ps1#L52) for exactly this problem:

```powershell
    # Fix up permissions, since we've first run pwsh as root:
    # (irritating that chown can't handle ~)
    $refDir = Resolve-Path '~'
    $dstDir = Resolve-Path '~/.local/share/powershell'
    chown -R --reference=$refDir $dstDir
```

It seems it has been resolved in PowerShell 7.0.0-rc.1.

I'm closing this issue!

Thanks

Hmm... I tried to repro, but this time repro'ed a *different* "access denied" problem.

My repro steps were:
1. Using Hyper-V "Quick Create", create an Ubuntu 18.04.3 LTS virtual machine.
2. In the VM, download the RC1 .deb file for Ubuntu 18.04.
3. Install the MS GPG keys, and then install the .deb according to the "direct download" instructions.
4. `sudo bash` so that the first run of pwsh would be as the root user.
5. `pwsh-preview` and then run `dir`.

**Expected result:** it all works.
**Actual result:** an "access denied error: "Get-ChildItem: Access to the path '/home/dt29/shared-drives' is denied."

But that isn't what this Issue is about, and could be unrelated. So I continued with my repro.
6. `exit` the instance of `pwsh-preview` being run as root.
7. `exit` the instance of `bash` being run as root.
8. Now I'm back to my normal user account shell, and I run `pwsh-preview` again as a normal user.
9. Finally, I run `dir`.

**Expected result:** it all works; no errors.
**Actual result:** I get an "access denied" error accessing the PSReadLine history file, and then as an added bonus, the rest of the output of `dir` stays red.

I don't know if the original repro by @MaximoTrinidad used different repro steps. Perhaps his problem was unrelated, and has been fixed. But my problem--where if the first time you run pwsh, you run as root, and then permissions are messed up for the normal user--is unchanged.

And of course, note that the "real" reason that I end up in this situation is not because I manually switch to the superuser for the first run, but because I have a bootstrapping/setup script that I run, which does many privileged things (like installing software), so it's run as root, of course, and it also runs PowerShell scripts (once PowerShell is installed), also of course. :)

That said, we still have #5239, so we don't need two Issues for this.

@jazzdelightsme Thanks for your investigations!

I see two issues:
1. Broken coloring after error
2. Broken permissions

I guess both is PSReadline issues /cc @daxian-dbw @SteveL-MSFT

Interesting!  I closed the issue after I rebuild my Ubuntu 18.04.3 VM and it did work for me.

![Ubuntu_2020-01-06_11-09-14](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19892435/71830768-72969700-3075-11ea-8384-17511448781a.png)
I'm reopening the issue until it gets confirmed it's OK.

@MaximoTrinidad I think #5239 has captured all information from here, right? If so, we can close this one as a duplicate.
BTW, in your comment https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/10601#issuecomment-571200581, you didn't launch `pwsh` the first time as the root user, did you?

@daxian-dbw 

Sounds Good! I will close this issue.

Thanks
:)

the quickest way to resolve is by changing the path for Powershell History Save 
below is the command that will help resolving the issue 

Set-PSReadLineOption -HistorySavePath <Path>
